awd_titl_txt: Motor Exploration and Motor Learning During Child Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine how children's ability to explore different movement patterns affects their ability to learn new motor skills. This project will enhance basic understanding of the differences between how children and adults learn to acquire such motor skills, which will provide theoretical insight into how the brain organizes movement and learning. The knowledge gained from this project has important implications for how learning and rehabilitation paradigms should be customized for children, especially in cases of movement disorders such as cerebral palsy.  The project will also include an outreach component to involve middle and high-school students in STEM research. Because children are not simply smaller versions of adults, rehabilitation programs must be tailored in age-specific manners; by adopting a developmental focus, this research will facilitate the creation of such child-appropriate programs.

Although there is evidence that children and adults differ in terms of motor learning, the mechanisms underlying these differences are poorly understood. The investigators hypothesize that motor exploration--the ability to generate different movement patterns--may play a critical role in this difference. This project examines the role of motor exploration in motor learning with a specific focus on how this relation changes with development during childhood. Specifically, the investigators attempt to answer three research questions: (1) how does motor exploration during learning change with development, (2) how does age mediate the relation between motor exploration and learning, and (3) can practice schedules that modify motor exploration be used to facilitate learning? The investigators use a novel paradigm called a body-machine interface to minimize typical confounds (such as body size and strength) to compare motor learning across different age groups. This research will contribute to a more elaborated understanding of how children acquire complex motor skills during development.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project examined how children's ability to explore different movement patterns affects their ability to learn new motor skills. Motor exploration involves creating different variations in behavior before selecting those that lead to better outcomes. Examining the role of motor exploration in learning a new motor task, especially considering its impact across development, can offer valuable insights into specific learning mechanisms. Furthermore, this understanding can serve as a foundation for developing innovative rehabilitation approaches in the treatment of movement disorders in pediatric patients.

The primary outcomes of the study indicate that, even with the implementation of a novel task protocol to mitigate influences stemming from task familiarity and biomechanical differences, children showed lower task performance after similar amounts of practice when compared to young adults. Notably, this diminished task performance in children was found to be associated with a limited exploration of the movement repertoire during learning. We further examined if such differences between children and adults persist across relatively long practice periods. Our results showed that even though all age groups improved with practice, age-related differences in task performance were persistent even after 5 days of practice. However, in simpler tasks (which do not require exploration), children showed greater exploration compared to young adults, indicating that children do not match exploration to task demands. These results point to the importance of understanding exploration throughout child development.

The development of this novel experimental paradigm to understand age-related differences within the project has proven to be particularly valuable. This experimental template serves as an ideal model for studying the impact of age-related exploration on learning a new task, minimizing confounding factors related to task familiarity and differences in body size.

This project has provided an opportunity to integrate research into educational settings within the Kinesiology department for graduate students. Additionally, undergraduate students from various departments, including Human Biology, Mechanical Engineering, Chemistry, and Kinesiology, have been involved. There were 2 graduate students and 23 undergraduate students who actively participated in tasks such as data collection, analysis of experimental data, presentation of results at conferences and meetings, and manuscript writing. These have resulted in 12 manuscripts related to the project. We also took part in outreach activities tailored for both the general public and school-aged students, participating in events such as the Michigan State Science Festival and Grandparents University. Our main goal during these initiatives was to highlight the exciting potential of STEM research and careers, underscoring their pivotal role in addressing important societal challenges.


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Mei-Hua Lee
